title: Acting intelligence chief says whistleblower did ‘right thing’ with Trump complaint
text:
Getty Images Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire testifies before the House Select Committee on Intelligence on September 26, 2019 in Washington.

A whistleblower “did the right thing” in filing a complaint that alleges President Donald Trump sought foreign interference in U.S. elections and that the White House tried to “lock down” details of a call between Trump and Ukraine’s president, the acting director of national intelligence told lawmakers Thursday.

Testifying before the House Intelligence Committee, acting DNI Joseph Maguire called the matter “unprecedented.”

See: Whistleblower alleges Trump White House moved records onto separate network.

The whistleblower complaint filed in August prompted scrutiny of Trump’s July call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. In that call, Trump pressed Zelensky to probe former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, according to a summary of the conversation released by the White House on Wednesday.

Read text of whistleblower complaint.

Trump has denied wrongdoing and most Republicans have defended him, but at least one, Rep. Mike Turner of Ohio, said during the hearing that Trump’s conversation with Zelensky was “not OK” and called it “disappointing to the American public.”

Democrats have criticized Maguire for withholding the complaint, which was released on Thursday morning. Maguire said he could not release it due to executive privilege, which he didn’t have the authority to waive.

Asked if Trump or other U.S. officials asked him to identify the whistleblower, Maguire replied “emphatically, no.”

The House hearing came after Speaker Nancy Pelosi this week decided to move ahead with an impeachment inquiry into Trump.

U.S. stocks on Thursday dipped amid Maguire’s testimony and the release of the complaint. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.33%, S&P 500 index SPX, -0.44% and Nasdaq COMP, -0.73% were all trading modestly lower.

See also: Stocks edge lower as investors weigh impeachment concerns with trade optimism.
